The green curry and Szechuan peppercorn chicken are really ordinary, and the seasoning is quite strange.
The soup base wasn't very rich, I think it could be a bit more flavorful to live up to its "sour and spicy" name.
The Thai red milk tea (Thai milk tea) is sweet enough and delicious.
The Thai milk tea is sweet yet surprisingly smooth, I personally think it's a must-order.
Highly recommend taking home their braised saltwater duck to enjoy at your leisure.
The duck noodle soup is a must-try, and it also comes with a lot of vegetables.
The noodles are thicker and chewier than those at a typical noodle shop, which is very good.
The must-order braised dish for takeout is definitely the braised beef shank; I love its sauce.
The saltwater duck meat is springy and quite salty.
The braised pig intestines are springy and seasoned great, but almost none of the fat in the middle was removed, making it too oily!
The duck meat has a moderate amount of fat and tender texture, very delicious.
The side dishes are not sloppy at all, you can tell the quality of the ingredients is very good.
There was a layer of duck fat floating on top of the pickled cabbage duck soup, but it didn't taste greasy at all.
The pickled cabbage duck soup is very aromatic and sweet, and there's no MSG-induced thirst after drinking it.
The duck rice and duck noodles come with many side dishes, and the duck meat is also very tender.
The braised beef tendon is quite flavorful, highly recommended.
Common braised dishes like dried tofu or duck eggs are not highly recommended.
The braised meat dishes are truly delicious, no doubt about it.
A portion of blanched vegetables costs 50 and the quantity is not small; it's quite good by takeout standards.
Recommend duck intestines, rock sugar braised chicken, and dried bamboo shoots.
The saltwater duck and rock sugar duck are both delicious to buy home and pair with wine!
The roasted chicken and sauce are too sweet; duck wings are the top choice.
The sesame sauce dry noodles with pickled mustard greens and vegetables had an unclear taste.
The chicken noodles with vegetables, the noodles had little flavor, but the soup base was okay.
The saltwater duck had little flavor and was ordinary, and the price was a bit expensive.
The thin-crust pizza is quite delicious.
Although the squid ink pasta is not as delicious as before, it's still considered good.
The crispy pork hock skin is very crispy and the meat is very tender, super delicious with sweet and sour sauce.
The squid ink pasta had little flavor, but the squid was very tender and wouldn't make your mouth tired from chewing.
The corn cake platter is decent; it's not bad, but I wouldn't order it unless I was very hungry.
The seafood chowder has a lot of ingredients.
But speaking of the cheese chicken quesadilla, that one is impressive.
They weren't shy with the cheese, adding tons of it. Eaten with the side salad, sour cream, and avocado, I'm telling you, it's super delicious.
The meals are up to standard, decent but not particularly amazing.
The drinks are not bad, but I wouldn't feel like ordering another pot.
Homemade smoked chicken and spinach ravioli, the Italian red sauce was very rich, but unfortunately it overpowered the flavor of the ravioli filling.
The German pork hock is said to be a signature dish, but the texture was a bit dry and tough, and the taste wasn't to my liking.
It was surrounded by some mashed potatoes or bean paste, making the whole dish moist and sticky, not refreshing to eat.
The crispy fried mozzarella cheese has a flaky and crispy crust wrapping thick cheese.
Smoked pork ribs, the smoky sauce is rich and unique.
The meat is fibrous but not dry, with a hint of pesto, leaving a fragrant aftertaste.
Beef lasagna, with layers of tomato, minced beef, cheese, and béchamel sauce wrapped in pasta, I personally really like it.
Classic Caesar salad, the rich Caesar dressing paired with abundant fresh greens, crispy bacon, and Parmesan cheese is truly refreshing and helps cut through richness.
The special chef's fresh soup is like McDonald's corn soup, quite ordinary.
The mixed seafood pizza has a thin crust, and the toppings are very generous, so you get ingredients in every bite.
The signature crispy roasted German pork hock is, in my opinion, not a must-order.
It's a pretty good German pork knuckle, but it won't amaze you.
I highly recommend the homemade chicken spinach cheese ring pasta; it's very special.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Homemade chicken spinach cheese ring pasta

Text: The ring pasta is somewhat like wontons with filling, but the wrapper is much thicker than wontons, and it's really fragrant when paired with the rich and thick truffle sauce.
The cream sauce is based on seafood broth, the cheese portion is ample, and the sauce is thick.
Most importantly, all the dishes are very delicious; it can be said that the meals are great value for money.
The golden crispy squid strips are pretty good, and the portion is quite large, recommended for four or five people to share.
The German pork knuckle is highly recommended by the staff; the pork knuckle is crispy on the outside and very fragrant.
My friend said this pork knuckle is one of the best he has ever eaten; the portion is large and the sauerkraut is pretty good.
This Black Forest fried rice, a vegetarian fried rice without egg, is actually more delicious than non-vegetarian dishes. It's super fragrant and the sauce is so tasty.
The staff also highly recommend the homemade chicken spinach cheese ring pasta; it's a strong recommendation and very memorable.
It tastes like a slightly thick but elastic dumpling wrapper, paired with a rich sauce; it's amazing, the first time I've had such a creative dish.
The cheese seafood baked rice is pretty good; using turmeric rice isn't very unique as it's common elsewhere, but the ingredients are quite plentiful.
The Mexican pesto stir-fried beef flap is a bit too oily, but it's very fragrant and delicious; if there are many people, you can share it.
The cranberry strawberry juice is delicious.
Birthday celebrants of the month can get a free cake by showing proof, but the cake wasn't very tasty.
The signature pork ribs are still a delicious must-order, though this time the meat of the ribs was a bit tough.
Highly recommend the Mexican mini fried rolls and mozzarella cheese with salsa; they're delicious.
The cheese pancake is also very delicious.
Today I had an extremely poor dining experience and unbelievably bad service quality.
The first problem was the soft-shell Mexican wrap; upon cutting it open, there was a very strong smell of beefiness.
The texture was also quite hard; overall, it wasn't fresh beef.
Eating the mashed potatoes alone, it didn't feel fresh, and there was a strong rancid oil smell.
The shrimp in the seafood chowder weren't fresh at all, had no sweetness, and a very hard texture.
The dishes are Western-style; they are slightly ordinary, and the taste is a bit salty.
The pork knuckle is crispy on the outside and tender on the inside, but the crispy skin is a bit too hard to chew.

Quadruplet.Opinion: crispy on the outside and tender on the inside

Text: There are Chinese dishes with light flavors, but they all taste good.
The ingredients are quite fresh, and all the seasonings and sauces are provided, truly a good choice for future Chinese New Year catering.
The shredded pork with pickled mustard greens noodles was a disappointment; I suggest changing the noodles.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Shredded pork with pickled mustard greens noodles

Text: The orange ribs are fried crispy, and the sauce is smooth and moist.
The potstickers, $110 for 8 pieces, are fried very crispy, and the filling has some juice; they are very delicious.
The fried egg was burnt, and the hot and sour soup was too sour. The only positive was that the manager apologized.
The cassia seed barley tea is refreshing, rich in flavor, and delicious.
The steamed dumplings are very large, with chewy wrappers and plump fillings.
The pancake wrapper is amazing, and the pork slices are firm and chewy.
The exterior of the beef roll is all greasy, and it's filled with sweet soy sauce paste.
The taste of the crab roe tofu pot is good, it's a top-notch dish.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Taste of the crab roe tofu pot

Text: The sweet flatbread is delicious, sweet enough, flavorful, and very fragrant; it's a great experience.
The glass noodles are a bit hard to eat, and I personally don't like the overall seasoning.
The sesame oil for the Matsusaka pork (small) $190 was bitter, and the Matsusaka pork was tough to chew.
The steamed dumplings were extremely ordinary, and the quality was disappointing.
The side dishes tasted a bit sweet, and the texture wasn't very good.
The beef roll is filled with green onions and beef slices; the taste is refreshing and delicious.
The beef was super hard and fibrous, clearly meat that had been frozen for a long time, and it had a very strong gamy beef smell.
The side dish of shredded kelp was all oily, and the stir-fried cabbage was also very oily.
The scallion oil chicken for $180 was also quite amazing; the skin was roasted darker, but the texture was very tender.
The clear chicken soup tasted fresh and sweet, and with its medicinal herbal warmth, it warmed both the tongue and body.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Taste of the clear chicken soup

Text: The shredded pork and egg fried rice was okay in taste; order it if you need to eat rice.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Taste of shredded pork and egg fried rice

Text: The fresh shrimp steamed dumplings are delicious; you can taste the texture of the shrimp.
The stir-fried watercress is good, crispy and delicious.
The fried rice for 120 yuan is not cheap; the portion is sufficient, but it lacks wok hei, which is very disappointing.
The portion of vegetables is a bit small, 100 NTD is too expensive, and the taste is ordinary.
The millet porridge is worth trying; it contains oatmeal and has an excellent texture.
The main dishes, on the other hand, were a bit disappointing, which is a pity.
The steamed dumplings are filled with pork and chives; each one in the basket is plump, round, translucent, and shiny.
The steamed dumpling skin is thin, tender, and springy, not mushy at all.
The shredded pork and preserved vegetable noodles are decent, and the hand-shaved noodles have a firm and strong texture.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Shredded pork and preserved vegetable noodles

Text: The soup base is rather light and slightly bland; it improved a bit after adding black vinegar and a little soy sauce for flavor.
The flavor of the preserved vegetables was insufficient, which is a pity; I do not recommend ordering these shredded pork and preserved vegetable noodles.
The scallion pancake was thick enough but lacked fluffiness; the amount of scallions was slightly sparse, and the scallion aroma was insufficient.
The pig's head skin appetizer was thinly sliced but had a chewy and springy texture.
The dried anchovies were stir-fried with fermented black beans, scallion segments, and an unknown sauce, making them very flavorful.
The braised beef shank was very fragrant, but it might have been left on the appetizer counter for too long before serving, so it was a bit dry.
The golden kimchi had no significant highlights compared to others I've had on the market, so it's not recommended.
The hot and sour soup had a good taste and plenty of ingredients.
What stood out in the soup was the excessively thick-cut cabbage; only it was wider than a thumb.
The pork patty had a thin crust and a generous filling.
The pork patty crust was crispy, but unfortunately, there wasn't enough juice.
The steak is not recommended as it's super tough; the tomahawk pork chop is acceptable, but the hot pot is very ordinary.
I love the turmeric cheese milk hot pot the most; it's made with real ingredients and is very healthy.
My friend ordered the roasted spring chicken; the portion was very large, but the chicken was dry, possibly reheated, making this roasted spring chicken quite disappointing.
The cabbage and flatfish hot pot is delicious, with rich ingredients and even squid paste.
The cherry duck costs 490 NTD, which is a bit expensive; the plating is acceptable, but it tastes just average.
The sweet spinach is quite refreshing, and the grilled fish is also very delicious.
The winter melon tea and sour plum juice are also very good.
Every dish we ordered was delicious, especially recommended is the salted fish rice.
The soup base of the Goat Milk Tree Root Free-Range Chicken Hot Pot is rich, with a unique aroma I've never tasted before, and the chicken is also very tender and flavorful.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Goat Milk Tree Root Free-Range Chicken Hot Pot soup base

Text: The Chulu fresh milk steamed bun is crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, sprinkled with a little fine sugar powder on the surface; the fresh milk flavor is rich but not cloying.
The ostrich meat and lamb with skin are very appetizing with rice.
The egg-baked squid was already cold when served, which was the only downside.
The pig's trotters were over-roasted, dry, tough, and a bit hard.
The signature grilled fish had a very strong earthy taste, and the fish meat was mushy, probably not fresh; this grilled fish is highly not recommended.
The ginseng vegetable is very tender and has a very unique flavor.
I think the aboriginal zongzi made with millet and pork at this restaurant is very delicious; I couldn't stop eating one after another.
After business picked up, the food also became bad, and dishes were often served cold.
The chicken soup is not recommended; the meat is super tough and hard to chew.
When you bite into it, the pepper flavor is rich, and the chicken skin is very crispy; it's a chicken drumstick with a special flavor.
The salted fish wooden bucket rice uses pan-fried mackerel placed on white rice sprinkled with savory furikake, but the mackerel had a somewhat strong fishy smell.
The aboriginal dry noodles were surprisingly delicious; they use white noodles mixed with a garlic and lard sauce.
The truffle prawns were okay, and the grilled grouper (Saikyo-yaki) had very springy fish meat.
The stir-fried scallops with various mushrooms and seasonal vegetables were amazing, and the generous amount of scallops made it good value for money.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Stir-fried scallops with various mushrooms and seasonal vegetables

Text: The rose salt grilled Matsusaka pork was delicious, and the beef with sauce was very tender.
Only the lobster sandwich was a bit disappointing, with an extremely dry texture.
The thick-cut pork chop stone pot bibimbap had fragrant scorched rice, and the ingredients were quite rich.
The karaage chicken was very large, juicy, crispy outside, and tender inside.
The curry was a bit sweet, reminiscent of Vermont curry, and rather ordinary.
The pearl dessert was pretty good, leaving a sweet, honey-like taste of happiness in the mouth.
The miso soup, which can be refilled, contains tofu and ingredients similar to fried bean curd skin; it's smooth and not too salty, somewhat like a subtle miso soup.
The curry sauce for the pork cutlet curry was rich and went well with rice, but the pork cutlet itself was rather ordinary.
The karaage chicken was very large, with thin skin and tender meat, but unfortunately, it had a slight fishy taste.
The dessert tapioca ball soup was very good and not too sweet.
Then his rice was really a failure, it was soft but not chewy, not quite mushy but still didn't pass the mark.
The chawanmushi was substantial, with edible clams inside, and the egg was smooth, tender, and well-seasoned.
I ordered the 8oz sirloin steak; the steak had little flavor and a lot of fat.
The taste of the star fruit brine was very strong, and the dragon fruit was soft and mushy.
The sweet and sour pork was so tough it was hard to chew.

Quadruplet.Opinion: So tough it was hard to chew

Text: The stewed beef tendon was super delicious, and the large piece of tofu in the middle soaked up the sauce, making it great with rice.
A very generous amount of beef tendon was given, and it was stewed to be extremely tender; this was my favorite dish.
The chicken thigh skewer was very delicious, the meat was so tender and constantly dripping juice, and the chicken wing skin was super thin and crispy.
Water snowflake is a vegetable I really like, but this dish wasn't stir-fried perfectly.
The Mentaiko chicken thigh skewer was great, the mentaiko sauce was rich, and the chicken had no gamey smell, so I really liked it.
The clam meat in the sake-steamed clams was super plump, but there was no hint of sake aroma at all.
The Udon noodles were good, the portion was just right for two people, and the noodles melted in the mouth.
Finally, the corn was very fresh and sweet, and also had a charcoal aroma.
The tofu in the sesame tofu was firm, and it paired perfectly with the sesame sauce.
The grilled king oyster mushrooms were just right, flavorful with a soy aroma and not too dry.
Definitely do not order the charcoal grilled diced beef; the meat had a very strong gamey smell.
The hot pot dish had a rich and flavorful taste with a spicy kick, a truly good dish, and the best part is you can get free soup refills.
The basic ingredients in the hot pot were very rich, including tofu, tofu skin, cabbage, black fungus, etc., and each ingredient was braised to be flavorful, refreshing, and delicious.
The soup base, as is typical for southern flavors, was a bit sweet, which I'm not quite used to.
The shark meat with sauce on top was just average, and the three-color egg wasn't particularly outstanding either.
The braised pork rice had large pieces of lean meat that were slightly dry.
The hot pot with fish (2-3 servings, $320) had a very rich soup base flavor that couldn't be described with a single adjective.
The dishes served were not hot at all, and the braised pork rice was also unappetizing and completely lacking flavor.
The signature pork thick soup noodles had genuine and substantial pork meatballs, though the pork meatballs were a bit soft.
The garlic collagen pork skin contained rich collagen; the pork skin was braised to be very flavorful and chewy.
The pork meatballs were quite crispy and flavorful.
Today I surprisingly discovered that this restaurant's signature pork hock is so delicious, I never knew before.
The fatty part of the pork knuckle was not greasy, but the lean meat was a bit dry, and the taste wasn't particularly outstanding.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Fatty part of the pork knuckle

Text: The steamed egg probably wasn't made with broth, and the quality of the eggs wasn't great, resulting in a noticeable eggy smell.
The price point is for refined snacks, but the taste is actually quite rough.
The side dishes, cucumber and braised dried tofu, were delicious, and I also liked the bamboo shoot rice.
The chawanmushi contained mushrooms, and the steamed egg was dense and smooth, without a watery texture.
The signature pork hock was braised to be very flavorful, and personally, I found the fatty meat not too greasy, full of collagen, and I ate it all.
The miso tofu soup came in a super large bowl with lots of tofu; it was made with genuine ingredients.
Among the side dishes, the braised cabbage was the most delicious, but the dried bamboo shoots were too sweet.
The sauce on the pork skin was super sticky, and the pork skin was too soft and mushy, resulting in a poor texture.
The meatball in the meatball soup had too much flour mixed in, lacking a meaty texture and not tasting good, and the soup base had no flavor.
That day we ordered beef and chicken thigh; the beef had a delicate texture, and the chicken thigh was elastic and chewy.
The rice had my preferred texture, with distinct grains and an aroma of chicken oil.
The chicken rice had fried shallots, and the shallot oil flavor was very rich and fragrant.
The fish skin soup was very fresh, and the milkfish belly was not fishy at all, and very sweet.
The pan-fried fish intestines I randomly ordered had a somewhat strong taste; I personally needed to dip it in mustard soy sauce to make it less nauseating.
The dried flounder with cabbage was a miss for me today; I actually found a rough and hard bone from the dried flounder stuck directly in my teeth.
The fish skin soup is definitely a must-order signature dish, full of fish skin with a bit of fish meat, rich in collagen and smooth in texture.
Today I ordered savory porridge, fish skin soup, and pan-fried milkfish belly; every dish was very delicious, especially the fish skin soup, which had no fishy smell at all with its skin and soup.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Savory porridge and fish skin soup

Text: The taste of the pan-fried milkfish was a bit heavier, and the oily taste was also more noticeable, but the meat quality was good, and I also liked its slightly crispy texture.
The braised pork rice was very greasy to eat; don't order it.
The fish skin side of the pan-fried fish belly was a bit lacking in crispiness, and I felt it could use a little more salt for seasoning, but it was still very oily, fragrant, and delicious.
The fish skin soup was an absolute delicacy; a generous amount of fish skin was given, still attached with plenty of meat, and most importantly, it was very fresh and sweet.
Although the milkfish was fragrant, crispy, and delicious, it was obvious that a lot of oil was used for shallow frying, making it a bit greasy by the end.
The fish maw skin is very crispy, and the dried bamboo shoots have a good texture, not too salty or too sour.
The fish intestines were a bit disappointing, as they were fried too dry and were cold when served.
The minced pork sauce for the Braised Pork Rice is not overly salty and has a gelatinous texture, but the rice is a bit hard.
The flatfish with cabbage was a bit cold; it would taste better hot.
The gravy-soaked fried dough sticks were a bit cold and had a poor texture.
The fried rice grains were distinct, and it was very fragrant.
The roasted duck was also delicious with crispy skin and rich fat, and the dipping sauce was truly special.
The signature beer duck soup base is delicious; you could drink several bowls of the soup alone.
The à la carte sakura shrimp oil rice had no flavor; I originally thought the sakura shrimp would be mixed in during cooking, but it was just sprinkled on top.
The wide noodles were cooked perfectly and immediately scooped out, making them very smooth and delicious.
The duck meat was not dry, the sauce was not too salty, the skin was not too greasy, and the scallions were fresh.
The condensed milk spiral rolls are small silver thread rolls but have more layers than typical silver thread rolls, and they are crispy, moist, and tasty when dipped in condensed milk.
The Northeast mixed salad was not fresh, the peanut oil had a strong rancid taste, and the stir-fried cabbage with sakura shrimp was very ordinary.
The vegetables and sakura shrimp were not flavorful, and the cabbage was tasteless.
Even the most basic stir-fried cabbage with sakura shrimp was so disappointing.
The portion of crispy fried pig intestines was small; for $320 a plate, I'd rather buy four lunchboxes. And the diced cod with crispy soybeans was just too small.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Portion of crispy fried pig intestines

Text: There was too much crispy soybean topping, and it was very hard and difficult to eat; I've never had such terrible plain rice.
The rice quality was poor, the rice grains were undercooked, leaving me in a bad mood after eating.
Even the most famous roasted duck was disappointing; without dipping it in sweet bean paste, it had absolutely no flavor and was difficult to eat.
Although the taste is slightly different from the original location, the soup base is still fresh, sweet, and rich, becoming smoother the more you drink.
The fried rice grains were distinct and retained a moist texture, but the rice was not overcooked.
The stone shrimp were fresh and had a firm texture.
Although this restaurant specializes in sliced duck, the sliced duck meat was a bit dry, and the taste was not really impressive.
I really think the roasted duck needs improvement.
I personally really like the assorted fried rice; it has a lot of ingredients like squid, shredded pork, and shrimp, and it's not greasy and tastes very good.
The specially ordered roasted duck platter was only served after all other dishes, and it was already cold.
The fried rice and other dishes were served immediately, but none of them were piping hot.
The fried rice grains were all stuck together, and the steamed dumpling filling was powdery; overall, the dishes' flavors were not outstanding.
The beer duck lacked character, with an overwhelming pepper taste; the cold appetizers were alright.
The cod was fresh, but its aroma was not quite strong enough.
When the signature whole duck finally arrived, it was cold and dry, God knows how long it had been sitting there; I've never had such terrible Peking duck.
If the signature dishes are this bad, there's no need to talk about the other dishes; it's a terrible restaurant.
The Mapo Tofu was bland, the Pig Intestines and Duck Blood in Spicy Sauce were bland, and the Shredded Pork with Beijing Sauce was too sweet and had a fishy smell.
The scallion pancake was essentially just a Sanxing scallion pancake sold at street stalls; I originally thought it was a handmade scallion pancake by the chef, which was truly disappointing.
The cabbage didn't feel stir-fried; it was soft and mushy, like blanched vegetables.
The roasted duck was indeed delicious, but the slicing technique was really poor.
What's even more ridiculous is that the fried rice grains were undercooked that day; it was the worst fried rice I've ever had in my life.
Zhuju Teahouse specializes in Cantonese dim sum, and various types of siu mai and roasted meats are of a certain standard.
The Three Cup Grouper was slightly spicy, delicious, and appetizing.
This time, we mainly ordered Hong Kong-style dim sum. The filling of the Shanghai xiao long bao was very fragrant, six pieces for $200, and the skin had a great texture.
For the Cantonese cherry duck, I found the peanut sauce very strange and it didn't add anything; moreover, the duck meat was dry and stringy with no juice.
The flavors of the Hong Kong-style dim sum were all very peculiar; the taste and texture of the char siu pastry were shocking, feeling like reheated food.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Flavors of Hong Kong-style dim sum

Text: The shrimp rice rolls had a slight sour taste; I wasn't sure if it was from vinegar or if the food had gone bad.
The skin of the rice rolls was unusually thick.
The red crabs were quite delicious and fresh.
The Buddha Jumps Over the Wall soup also had very generous ingredients; every spoonful was full of ingredients.

Quadruplet.Aspect: Ingredients of Buddha Jumps Over the Wall soup

Text: It's just a bit of a shame about the dessert; the sago part was a bit weak.
The No. 2 Taro Paste Crispy Duck was super crispy, with an incredibly abundant and rich taro paste; both the texture and taste were superb.
The Cantonese fried rice contained large shrimp, meat, and dried shrimp, with distinct rice grains, making it excellent.
The siu mai and pearl meatballs had a good texture, but they tasted rather simple and plain.
The skin of the soup dumplings is a bit thick, and the filling tastes not much different whether eaten plain or with sauce.

Quadruplet.Aspect: The skin of the soup dumplings

Text: The hot tea is delicious and impressive, and one pot is quite a generous portion.
Although it's free shrimp shell soup, it's very rich and delicious.
The shrimp are specially seasoned, large, and delicious.
The Matsusaka pork rice also features specially marinated Matsusaka pork, which is fresh, tender, and delicious.
The rice is very moist and sticky, lacking the aroma or texture that fried rice should have.
The wok aroma of the fried rice is abundant, and it's distinct grain by grain.

Quadruplet.Aspect: The wok aroma of the fried rice

Text: The freshness of the shrimp itself is not bad, and the meat is very springy.

Quadruplet.Aspect: The freshness of the shrimp itself

Text: Neither the shrimp flavor nor the miso flavor is too strong, overall it's quite good.
The signature premium shrimp rice (NT130) looks like a small bowl but is very generous in portion.
The shrimp are large, elastic, and flavorful, and the shrimp tails get more fragrant the more you chew them.
The restaurant's homemade chili oil is slightly spicy and aromatic, adding it to the rice has a bonus effect.
The broth is refreshing yet has a rich shrimp flavor. Green onions and onions can be added to enhance the texture and add a slightly pungent and spicy taste.
Shrimp fried rice (individual) $130, because the expectations were high, I was a little disappointed with the rice itself in the fried rice; it was distinct grain by grain but lacked wok hei.

Quadruplet.Aspect: The rice in the fried rice

Text: The shrimp texture is springy and elastic; the shrimp are all fried before stir-frying, which is really delicious.
The surf and turf cold noodles are also delicious for $100.
The shrimp head soup has a distinct and strong shrimp flavor.
The fried rice is a bit oily; towards the end, you'll see some oil accumulation at the bottom.
The price of the shrimp rice is quite high (it's shrimp, after all), but the taste is good.

Quadruplet.Aspect: The price of the shrimp rice

Text: The offal soup broth is rich, but it feels a bit oily towards the end.
The duck meat has a gamy smell, and there's very little duck meat; the large bowl just has more rice.
There isn't much duck meat in the duck rice, but the meat has a good balance of fat and lean.
The stewed duck soup has a rich flavor and tastes better than the duck soup with shredded ginger.

Text: The soup is a bit too oily.
The blanched greens are very tender and fresh.
The offal in the offal soup was overcooked, very tough and hard to chew.
Greens tossed with rich duck oil, how could it not be delicious?
The large plate of sliced duck (180 NTD) is quite generous in portion, with a fresh, tender, and juicy texture.
Large duck rice (40 NTD) - I think the saltiness is just right and goes well with rice.
Duck vermicelli (50 NTD) - The broth is a little bit oily but still acceptable.
Duck soup with shredded ginger (40 NTD) - The duck meat tasted a bit dry and tough.
Duck heart (50 NTD) - Quite delicious, not mushy in texture.
Duck blood cake (25 NTD) - The texture is relatively soft and moist.
The portion of sliced duck was more than expected, and the taste was good, but unfortunately, the skin was too thick and hard to chew.
The duck meat in the duck rice has a bland taste.
The duck vermicelli has a very light flavor.
The regular duck soup with shredded ginger is a bit oily and ordinary, but the old soup might have had blood, so the umami came through and was quite good.
What was more surprising was that the sweet potato leaves seemed to have been properly destrung, so the texture was truly tender.
The duck rice is moist enough and not bad, the taste is acceptable.
The portion of duck meat given is quite generous, and the offal is easy to eat.
The meat chunks in the stewed duck soup are also large, and the broth is delicious.

Text: Specializes in duck meat, but the duck meat was ordinary.
There's very, very little meat on the duck rice; it's truly just minced meat.

Quadruplet.Aspect: The meat on the duck rice

Text: The duck meat is juicy, not dry, and has few bones.
The amount of meat in the duck soup with shredded ginger was more than expected, and the broth was also refreshing and sweet.

Text: The duck rice is generally topped with a wet sauce, and the taste is also good.
The sesame paste noodles have a peanut aroma, recommended.
My wonton soup's flavor wasn't as aromatic and was a bit bland, but for $30, it had 5 wontons.
The dry noodles portion is super generous, a small bowl is enough.
